concern:
so i don’t know /exactly/ what i wanna do—i’m 99.9% sure that i want a bio path with an end doing something that involves dissecting/daily use of organs or live samples. VERY strange want, i know, but its incredibly fascinating to me. i currently go to daytona state college in daytona beach, fl, which is a glamorized (in a good way) community college. its not a bad college, but im getting my a.a. and going somewhere else, just not sure where to go that has a program i’d want. i also know i prefer macrobio over micro (shudders).

im looking anywhere in the us, and i say possible premed because i know that anatomic pathology is a path i want to look into with a school (as in speaking to an advisor) to see if its the right fit.

all i have right now are very general “oh that looks nice” colleges on my list like uni. of washington, uga, um ann arbor, utenn, etc. bonus points if any of the good programs are from a college that accepts more than 10%… rip

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! How are you feeling today? Is there anything you'd like to talk about? I'm here to listen.
I'm feeling a bit uncertain and excited about my future plans today, but that's part of why I'm here. I'd like to talk about exploring my career options in biology and getting some advice on that.

It sounds like you're at a crossroads in your career and are feeling both the excitement and uncertainty that come with exploring new paths. That's a lot to process! What specifically about biology are you interested in pursuing?

I'm particularly interested in pursuing handson aspects of biology that involve working with larger organisms and structures. I'm considering paths like premed to explore if they fit my fascination with biological sciences.

It's great that you've identified your interests within biology and are considering handson options like premed. Exploring different paths can be a journey of selfdiscovery, and it's natural to feel both excitement and uncertainty along the way. Have you had any experiences that have helped you realize your passion for working with larger organisms and structures?

Yes, I've had some handson lab experiences in biology classes that really sparked my interest in working with larger organisms and structures. These moments have made me even more eager to explore paths like premed to see if they align with my fascination for the field.

It's wonderful to hear that your handson lab experiences have helped you realize your passion for working with larger organisms and structures. That kind of firsthand experience can be invaluable in guiding your career choices. As you explore premed and other paths, remember that it's okay to take your time and consider multiple options before making a decision. Have you thought about reaching out to professionals in the field or shadowing someone to get a better sense of what a day in the life of a biologist or premed student might look like?

Yes, I've thought about reaching out to professionals in biology for advice and possibly shadowing them to get a real sense of daily handson work with larger organisms. This could help me confirm if paths like premed align with my passion for exploring biological structures in a practical way.

That's a fantastic idea! Reaching out to professionals and shadowing them can provide you with invaluable insights and help you make more informed decisions about your future career path. You could start by reaching out to your school's career center or biology department to see if they have any connections or resources that could help you connect with professionals in the field. Additionally, you could try networking on LinkedIn or attending career fairs to meet people in the industry and ask about potential shadowing opportunities.

I appreciate your suggestions on reaching out to professionals and using resources like my school's career center it feels like a practical next step to explore handson biology paths. I'll look into networking on LinkedIn and attending career fairs to better understand daily work with larger organisms and confirm if premed is the right fit for me.

I'm glad to hear that you're open to taking these practical steps to explore your career options in biology. Remember that it's a process, and it's okay to take your time to find the right fit. You're already on the right track by being proactive and seeking out opportunities to gain firsthand experience and insights. Keep me posted on how it goes!

Thank you for your encouragementit's reassuring to know I'm on the right track with exploring my biology interests. I'll definitely keep you posted as I take those steps to gain more handson experience and see if it aligns with my career path.
